instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> without audio drivers.
threads.message: Hello, I have already changed <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6500</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6880</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6630</CHIP>, but it didn't work. I removed the <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> and it didn't work. I don't know what to do anymore, where to measure!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> without audio drivers.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> is the trick for missing speaker sound; stuk in SPDIF output.

Is the audio codec recognized in System Report?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> without audio drivers.
threads.message:
"" <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> is the trick for missing speaker sound; stuk in SPDIF output. ""

Big thanks for this,, Just helped me fix one I had in for a torn off speaker connector that had no sound after replacing the connector,
Removed <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR>  good as new!

Ledgend!
